title-group.article-title: Frequency features of basalt filament tows under quasi-static and high strain rate tension

article-meta.aff: College of Textiles, State Key Laboratory for Modification of Chemical Fibers and Polymer Materials, Donghua University, Shanghai, 201620, China

author-notes.corresp: Bohong Gu, College of Textiles, State Key Laboratory for Modification of Chemical Fibers and Polymer Materials, Donghua University, Shanghai, 201620, China Email: gubh@dhu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This paper reports the tensile behaviors of basalt filament tows under quasi-static and high strain rate tension in frequency domain. The tensile tests of the basalt filament tows under different strain rates (quasi-static: 0.001/s, dynamic: 600–3000/s) were performed on MTS810.23 materials test system and split Hopkinson tension bar (SHTB) system, respectively. It is shown that the mechanical properties of the basalt filament tows were strain-rate sensitive. The energy absorbed by the basalt filament tows increased with the strain rate. From fast Fourier transform (FFT) analysis of tension stress vs. time histories, the phase spectrum of the filament tows was dependent on the strain rate. The amplitude spectrum and power of energy absorption of the filament tows were concentrated on a specific frequency range and increased with the strain rate.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Basalt is an inert, naturally occurring, volcanic rock that has been found worldwide. Its chemical structure is nearly related to glass. The most important components of basalt are SiO2, Al2O3, CaO, MgO, Fe2O3, and FeO.1-5 The manufacture of basalt fiber requires the melting of the quarried basalt rock at about 1400°C. The molten rock is then extruded through small nozzles to produce continuous filaments of basalt fiber. The fibers typically have a filament diameter of between 9 and 13 µm which is far enough above the respiratory limit of 5 µm to make basalt fiber a suitable replacement for asbestos. Basalt fibers are more resistant to strong alkalis than glass fibers, but stability in strong acids is slightly lower. Basalt fiber can be used over a wide range of temperature, from –200 to 600°C. It shows high modulus, excellent heat resistance, heat and sound insulating properties, good resistance to chemical attack, and low water absorption.5 These advantages make basalt fibers a promising alternative to glass fibers as reinforcing material in composites. When considering the lower price of basalt fibers,5 it has been extensively come into consideration as potential reinforcement of composite materials over the last two decades.6-12

Largely driven by these applications, extensive works have been done to study the tensile property of basalt fibers in the past years.13-16 However, there are only a few studies concerned with the impact loading behaviors of the basalt fiber tows and composites because of the complexity of the materials responses in time domain.

Owing to the difficulty of establishing the constitutive equations of textile composite under impact loading, the frequency response analysis of the textile composites is an effective method to disclose the impact damage mechanisms and perhaps can find unknown behavior that is hidden in time domain. The authors of this article investigated the impact damage of 3-D textile composites in frequency domain, including the 3-D braided composite,17 3-D angle-interlock woven composite,18 multilayer multi-axial warp-knitted composite,19 and co-woven-knitted fabric (CWKF) composite.20 The damage mechanisms of the textile composite under the different strain rates were revealed for finding energy absorption features.

Here, we will investigate the tensile behaviors of the basalt fiber tows under the high strain rates in frequency domain using fast Fourier transform (FFT) method. We hope such an investigation can help us to understand the strain rate sensitivity and tensile impact behavior of the basalt fiber tows in the frequency domain.

sec.title: Experimental
sec.p:
The MTS 810.23 system (as shown in Figure 1) and a self-designed split Hopkinson tension bar (SHTB) apparatus (as shown in Figure 2) were used to test the basalt filament tows under quasi-static (with the strain rate is 0.001 s−1) and dynamic tensile test (with the strain rate ranging from 600 to 3000 s−1) loading conditions, respectively. Figure 1.
MTS810.23 materials test system. Figure 2.
Self-designed split Hopkinson tension bar (SHTB) apparatus.

sec.title: Filament fiber tows
sec.p:
The basalt filament tows used in the experiments were manufactured by Hengdian Group Shanghai Russia &Gold Basal Fiber Co. Ltd in China. The specifications of the fibers are listed in Table 1. Figure 3 is the photograph of the bobbin of basalt filament tows. Table 1.
Parameters of basalt filament tow
Filament tow fineness (Tex) Single fiber diameter (µm) Number of filament (n) Volume density (g/cm3)
2400 7 21,800 2.6
Figure 3.
Bobbin of basalt filament tows.

sec.title: Tension impact test and results
sec.p:
The basalt fiber tows and its connection with the SHTB bars are shown in Figure 4. In Figure 4, Ls is the testing span and Ls = 10 mm. The fiber tows were tested under room temperature and approximately 55% relative humidity. At least three fiber-tows were tested at each strain rate. The strain rate was controlled by adjusting the gas pressure of pressure vessel of the SHTB apparatus. Figure 4.
Basalt filament tows connected with Hopkinson bars.

Figure 5 is the stress-strain curves of basalt filament tows at different strain rates. It can be shown that the mechanical properties of basalt filament tows are obviously rate-dependent. Stress increases linearly initially, and then decrease after reaching the peak value. Young’s modulus and tensile strength increase with the increasing of the strain rate. However, the failure strain decreases with the increasing of the strain rate. Figure 5.
Stress-strain curves of basalt filament tows under various strain rates.

sec.title: Fractographs
sec.p:
In both the quasi-static and high strain rate tensile tests, the basalt filament tows fractured roughly near the center part of the fiber tow sample. Figure 6(a) shows typical damage fractographs of basalt fiber tows under high strain rate tension. It can be seen from the picture that the fibers failed more seriously in the part near the end-surface of the incident bar than that of the transimission bar. The fiber become sparse near the end of the incident bar due to some fibers being dropped from the specimen. During the high strain rate tension, the tensile stress wave traveled in the incident bar and passed through the basalt fibe tows, finally reaching the transmission bar. Part of the stress wave was reflected from the transmission bar and part of stress wave was absorbed by the damper of the SHTB apparatus. The basalt fiber tows near the incident bar absorbed more energy than another side near the transimission bar. This le to the more serious damage of fiber tows near the incident bar as shown in Figure 6(a). Figure 6.
Tensile failure of basalt filament tows under high strain rate tension. (a) Failure morphology of basalt filament tows under high strain rate tension and (b) microscopic fractograph.

Figure 6(b) shows the scanning electron microscope (SEM) fractograph of a single basalt fiber after high strain rate tension. It can be shown that the cross section of the basalt fiber is smooth. And the crack in the basalt fiber generated from the surface flaw and then propagated along cross-section direction, and finally fractured. This result indicates that the basalt filament tows break in a more brittle mode and the failure spread along the surface or inner defect as is shown in white arrow of Figure 6(b).

sec.title: FFT analyses of the tensile stress strain curves
Brief description of the FFT procedure
sec.p: An FFT is an efficient algorithm to compute the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) and its inverse. A DFT decomposes a sequence of values into components of different frequencies. This operation is useful in many fields but computing it directly from the definition is often too slow to be practical. An FFT is a way to compute the same result more quickly: computing a DFT of N points in the naive way, using the definition, takes O(N2) arithmetical operations, while an FFT can compute the same result in only O(NlogN) operations. The difference in speed can be substantial, especially for long data sets where N may be in the thousands or millions – in practice, the computation time can be reduced by several orders of magnitude in such cases, and the improvement is roughly proportional to N/log(N). This huge improvement made many DFT-based algorithms practical; FFTs are of great importance to a wide variety of applications, from digital signal processing and solving partial differential equations to algorithms for quick multiplication of large integers.

The most well-known FFT algorithms depend upon the factorization of N, but (contrary to popular misconception) there are FFTs with O(NlogN) complexity for all N, even for prime N. Many FFT algorithms only depend on the fact that e-2πiN is an Nth primitive root of unity, and thus can be applied to analogous transforms over any finite field, such as number-theoretic transforms.

Let {xi} be a sequence of length N, then its DFT is the sequence {Fn} given by
where the results are complex number with real and imaginary part, along with the corresponding amplitude and phase and calculated Power spectrum.

In all the FFT analyses, a commercial software of OriginLab OriginPro 8.5 was employed for FFT calculation. The input of FFT in OriginLab OriginPro 8.5 could be complex and of arbitrary size. It will not be padded with zeros or truncated but rather assumed to repeat periodically, with a period equal to the extent of input data.

sec.title: FFT analyses of the tension behavior
sec.p: During the high strain rate tension tests, the stress-time history could be recorded with the SHTB apparatus.21 The stress history in time domain can be transformed into frequency domain to find the damage features. The frequency features may help to find new information hidden in time domain by analyzing the mechanical properties of basalt filament tows using FFT method.

The amplitude, phase, and power spectrum of the basalt filament tows at quasi-static and high strain rate tension are summarized in Figures 7–9. From Figure 7, it is known that the amplitude distribution concentrates in the much low frequency region close to zero under quasi-static, but the amplitude distribution concentrates in a wide frequency region about 0–50 kHz under high strain rate state. In the frequency of 0–50 kHz, the amplitude of basalt fiber tows increases with increasing strain rate; in the frequency of 50–150 kHz, the amplitude fluctuates in a random way; and with the increasing of frequency, the amplitude nearly become 0. Figure 7.
Amplitude spectrum of the basalt filament tows under various strain rates. Figure 8.
Phase spectrum of the basalt filament tows under various strain rates. Figure 9.
Power spectrum of the basalt filament tows under various strain rates.

Figure 8 demonstrates the phase spectrum under various strain rates. These spectrums illustrate that the phase distribution of basalt fiber tows also concentrate in lower frequency region close to zero under quasi-static. Under high strain rate loading state, the frequency domain is distributed in a certain range from 0 to 500 kHz, and the phase decreases with the frequency. It can be speculated that the hysteresis of the basalt filament tows can be great under the dynamic loading of higher frequency domain.

The power spectrums at different strain rate of basalt filament tows are presented in Figure 9. It can be observed that the shape of the power spectrum curves in Figure 9 has the similar features as the amplitude spectrum. The energy power of the basalt filament tows at quasi-static state is located in much lower frequency region close to zero, and the energy power distribution concentrates in the region about 0–50 kHz under high strain rates. When the frequency region exceeds 50 kHz, the power has less fluctuations and decreases nearly to 0. In addition, it can be seen in Figure 9 that the power spectrums of basalt filament tows increases with the strain rate in the region of 0–50 kHz and the peak value can reach 20000 at the strain rate of 3000 s-1. These features manifest that the basalt filament tows have more potentiality of energy absorption under high strain rates than quasi-static loading under certain frequency region.

The energy absorption of the basalt filament tows under various strain rate, obtained by the stress-strain curves, is shown in Figure 10. It is observed that the absorbed energy of the basalt filament tows increases with increasing of strain rates. However, at the strain about 5%, the curve intersects in a point, and when the strain rate exceeds the point, the basalt filament tows have the reverse tendency of energy absorption with increasing of strain rates. Figure 10.
Effect of strain rate on the energy absorption of the basalt filament tows.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article reports the tension behaviors of the basalt fiber tows under quasi-static and high strain rates conditions. The FFT method was adopted to transform the stress time history into frequency domain. It has been observed that the basalt filament tows can absorb higher energy in a certain frequency region. The ability of energy absorption increases with increasing strain rates in certain frequencies. This indicates that the basalt fiber tows can be appropriately used in the impact loading conditions of certain frequency region. The stress-strain curves show that the basalt filament tows is sensitive to strain rate. The basalt fiber tows has better energy absorption ability when strain rate increases. The study could be benefit to the application of the structure design for the basalt filament tows as the reinforcing materials in the dynamic impact load condition.
